mdx.rawBody:
---
status: public
shortDescription: "A return statement can unwind multiple call stack frames"
shortCorrection: "A return statement pops exactly one call stack frame"
concepts:
  - Call
  - Return
  - Stack
  - Recursion
related:
  # - id: LiteralNoExpression
  #   relation: Special case
inOtherPl:
  - pl: Python
    id: ReturnUnwindsMultipleFrames
  # - pl: Python
  #   id: NoAtomicExpression
spec:
  - id: jls21
    sections: ["14.17"]
plVersion:
  # from: ecma6
  # to: ecma11
references:
  - citationKey: chiodiniSurveyingUpperSecondaryTeachers2025
    phenomena: [RUMF]
---

A `return` statement doesn't necessarily return to the call site
that called the current method,
but it can return at once from the callee,
its caller, the caller's caller, and so on.

childMdx.rawBody:
A `return` statement always returns to the call site
that called the current method.
It always unwinds only one call stack frame.
It only finishes the current method activation,
continuing execution right after the call site
who is responsible for the current activation.

So, in a sequence diagram,
this means a return arrow points to the same lifeline
from which the corresponding call arrow came.
It can't point to a different lifeline.

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    autonumber
    participant Driver
    participant Pedal
    participant Engine
    Driver->>Pedal: push()
    activate Pedal
    Pedal->>Engine: accelerate()
    activate Engine
    Engine-->>Pedal: return
    deactivate Engine
    Pedal-->>Driver: return
    deactivate Pedal
```

The call of `Pedal.push()` (1) is paired with return arrow (4),
and the call of `Engine.accelerate()` (2) is paired with return arrow (3).

A good way to detect this misconception is through the use
of (UML-like) sequence diagrams.
If the call and return arrows don't match up,
students might have this misconception.
Here is an example incorrect sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    autonumber
    participant Driver
    participant Pedal
    participant Engine
    Driver->>Pedal: push()
    activate Pedal
    Pedal->>Engine: accelerate()
    activate Engine
    Engine-->>Driver: return
    deactivate Engine
    deactivate Pedal
```

While there are two nested calls (1 and 2),
students may only draw a single return arrow (3)
that unwinds both stack frames.

While this misconception applies to returns in general,
it is particularly prevalent in returns from recursive calls.
Students sometimes assume that all calls in a recursion
can be completed at once by a single return statement.
That is, they assume a return statement unwinds the call stack
similar to the way an expression does.

### Exception Handling

If students assume that `return` unwinds multiple stack frames,
then they may be happy to learn that `throw` indeed may do so.
Thus, when clarifying this misconception,
one can explain that in exception handling
indeed multiple stack frames can be unwound
due to one single (`throw`) statement.

### Continuation-Passing Style, Asynchronous Calls, Multithreading

The following ideas are somewhat less directly related to this misconception,
but students may encounter them in more advanced courses.
There are various reasons why one might draw variants of sequence diagrams
where activations are not properly nested and properly delineated
by call arrows and return arrows.

For example, in _continuation-passing style_ (CPS),
methods never get to return.
A method always calls another method after it completes its own work.
The last method to be called then kills the entire program.
Thus no `return` ever happens.
This means that there won't be _any_ return arrows at all.
(However, if the last method did not kill the program,
then at that point the methods that had been called would
return one by one.)

Another example where sequence diagrams somewhat deviate from the simple model
are _asynchronous calls_ (calls to asynchronous APIs),
where a call _does_ return, immediately, just to the caller,
but the work on the callee may continue.
(In Java that work would happen in a different thread.)

In general, in _multi-threaded_ programs,
there will be multiple stacks,
each with its own proper nesting of calls and returns.
However, a sequence diagram may include special arrows
to denote communication between threads.
And that might include arrows
that are not paired with "return arrows".

frontmatter.shortDescription: A return statement can unwind multiple call stack frames
frontmatter.shortCorrection: A return statement pops exactly one call stack frame

phenomenonKinds.name: Mistakes

Confusing "short-circuit" evaluators with conventional logical operators
Using keywords as method or variable names

frontmatter.subjects: 542 hand-drawn expression trees from 12 exams in 6 university courses

phenomenonKinds.name: Diagram mistakes
phenomenonKinds.description: Mistakes in student-drawn expression trees, related to structure, types, or values

phenomena.name: A literal is inlined into the parent node
A simple variable access or field access is inlined into the parent node
The target (expression before dot) has been inlined (e.g., into a method invocation or a field access with explicit targets).
The index in an array access expression has been inlined.
Token 'new' is kept in separate node, which possibly includes a hole for connection.
Binary operator that is left-to-right associative is treated as right-to-left associative.
The tree is primarily a chain, reflecting, in order (e.g., left to right -> top to bottom) the constructs of the source code.
A node is replaced with a subtree containing code that appears inside methods or constructors called by the expression.
An *implicit* this is explicitly reported in the expression tree.
Access to the length field of an array is represented with extra parentheses.
A method / constructor with no arguments is represented in the tree with its proper name but without parentheses.
Missing token 'new' in a class, interface, or array instance creation.
A literal is missing the type annotation.
A simple variable access is missing the type annotation.
The type of the node is not the actual type of the node, but rather the type specified for the surrounding 'hole'.
The type of a character literal node is String.
A literal is missing the value annotation.
A simple variable access is missing the value annotation.
String value reported without quotes.
Both branches of a conditional expression are annotated with values.
